field_reports.description: From 24 February  till 26 July 2022 approx 38822 persons from Ukraine registered at least one overnigth stay in Slovenia. 6894 persons requested temporary and 380 international protection. Government Office for support and integration of migrants is the main government body providing reception and integration support to persons in need.
field_reports.summary: SVN: Population Movement - 2022- Ukraine humanitarian assistance (2022-08-01)

field_reports.description:
Approximately 50% of Ukrainians have already received Temporary Residence Permit in Lithuania.
LRC is preparing Country Plan to respond to Population Movement crisis.
Mid-term response will include on Cash and Voucher assistance to most vulnerable persons and families from Ukraine. 
LRC will also focus on information provision to people from Ukraine regarding State support so that more people are involved in social security net.

contacts.name: Florent VALLEE
contacts.title: Director of Emergency and Rescue Operations

field_reports.description:
According to French governement, in France, nearly 48,776 displaced persons were counted at the entrance to the national territory by the border police (PAF) between 24 February and 21 April 2022, 98% of whom were Ukrainian nationals.
The majority of arrivals in France were in the Alpes-Maritimes, the Grand Est region, the Ile de France region and Auvergne Rhône Alpes.

Most of these displaced persons arrived by land (48.1%), by air (31.3%) and by rail (14%).

On 24 th of February, the military operation launched by the Russian Federation caused a humanitarian crisis that affected over 18 Millon in Ukraine and neighboring countries. More than a quarter of the Ukrainian population has been forcibly displaced by the ongoing military attack.
As of 82 th day of the conflict, nearly 7.7 Million people were forcibly displaced internally and more than 6 million have crossed international borders and sought asylum in countries such as Poland, Romania, Hungary, Slovakia, Moldova and Belarus. The civilian toll of the ongoing military attack stands at 7389, including 3573 killed and 3816 injured according to the United Nations.
field_reports.summary: UKR: Population Movement - 2022-02 - Turkish Red Crescent Ukraine Humanitarian Aid Operations Report  #9 (2022-04-12)

field_reports.description:
The Government of Georgia adopted the Decree N387 of 2 March 2022, which concerns measures to be undertaken due to military actions in Ukraine. The LEPL National Tourism Administration of Georgia was assigned as a designated authority entrusted to organize accommodation, transportation and food supply for Ukrainian nationals and their family members (family is defined broadly: sister, brother, parents, grandparents) who have entered Georgia 1-23 February. All costs associated to the above shall be paid from 2022 State Budget.  Further, Ukrainian nationals are provided with free access to the emergency medical services, including COVID-19 treatment, vaccination and testing free of charge.
approximately 18,000 Ukrainians are currently in Georgia, with an average of 500 Ukrainians arriving in Batumi and/or Kutaisi a weekly basis, and 500 arriving daily in Tbilisi. There is also information regarding the departures, but it is not clear which Ukrainians are moving on. Some Ukrainian families willing to cross to Georgia are blocked at the Russian border. In line with the increasing number of the people coming from Ukraine the need of humanitarian aid is increasing. While healthcare and access to basic services seem to be globally covered, accommodation remains the biggest challenge. The Government has concerns regarding the numbers, criteria for prioritization. The problem remains with regard to Ukrainians who arrive after 23 February and do not fall under the government initiative of free accommodation scheme. The Tourism Agency hotline 144 is easily reachable, however does not offer any options for the newly arrived Ukrainians. They are all referred to the Migration Department and the Ukrainian Embassy with no particular solutions. The 3 main reasons were identified for Ukrainian arrivals to Georgia: 1. Family ties or friends 2. Georgian and mixed ethnicity 3. Cultural similarity. 
The Government is working to elaborate a package of services for Ukrainians, expected to include simplified procedure to access to primary/secondary education as well as pre-school education (MoE), removal of service fees at Public Service Development Agency’s level (MoJ), health and social protection (MoH), some kind of legal status (MIA).
field_reports.summary: GEO: Other - 2022-02 - Situation Update Ukraine-Georgia #1 (2022-04-11)

contacts.name: Pepe Sanchez / Iñigo Vila

contacts.name: Florent VALLEE
contacts.title: Director of Emergency and Rescue Operations

field_reports.description:
In France, more than 40,000 persons fleeing Ukraine were counted at the entrance to the national territory by the border police (PAF) between February 24 and April 5, 2022, 98% of whom were Ukrainian nationals.

The majority of arrivals in France were in the Alpes-Maritimes, the Grand Est region, and the Ile-de-France.

Most of these displaced persons arrived by land (49%), by air (31.8%), and by rail (14.5%).

Ukranian refugees have arrived in the Netherlands from the beginning of March onwards. Most people arrive by international train from Germany and via other means of transportation (such as via airports and by bus). Humanitarian assistance is needed in terms of shelter and other basic needs in shelter locations. Since most Ukranians won't be seen as asylum seekers, the government has initiated a certain status for the people so the process of shelter and other assistance is different from asylum seekers.
field_reports.summary: NLD: Population Movement - 2022-03 - Ukraine humanitarian assistance #1 (2022-04-06)

field_reports.description: Assist of the Hellenic Red Cross to the Ukraine Red Cross.
field_reports.summary: GRC: Population Movement - 2022-02 - Hellenic Red Cross Humanitarian Aid to Ukraine #1 (2022-04-01)

field_reports.description: The security situation across Ukraine changed rapidly. The intense hostilities have resulted in the loss of life, injuries and mass movement of the civilian population throughout the country and to neighboring countries. The ongoing armed conflict has put hundreds of thousands of people’s lives at risk and created new humanitarian needs among millions of Ukrainians. Some categories of vulnerable population (elderly/ people with disabilities) have no ability to relocate and stay blocked in their houses, struggling to meet very basic needs. Access to basic medical services become more and more challenging as a result of disrupted supply chains. Some areas face the damaged services with no ability to fix them (water supply, centralized heating, electricity supply)- which exacerbates the humanitarian crisis. Critical needs must be addressed urgently.
field_reports.summary: UKR: Complex Emergency - 2022-02 - Emergency response to the most vulnerable people in the East of Ukraine #8 (2022-03-29)

Since 11/03 arrivals are increasing constantly facilitated by the collaboration between SNCF (French railway company) and RENFE (Spanish railway company) with free tickets and special trains arriving from Paris to Barcelona and from there to different cities in Spain. Also by different initiatives of citizenship with buses and cars arriving to different points of the country. It is expected that arrivals will increase signifcantly although there are no official projections.

field_reports.description:
Since the conflict started on 24 February 2022 in Ukraine the Albanian Red Cross has been following up closely the development situation there, especially in civilian population impact and humanitarian aspects. Staying updated with all information's coming up from media  for numbers of people affected like deaths, wounded, displaced in and out of the country, Albanian Red Cross decided to organize a fund raising campaign in our country  collecting funds from general public and institutions. For this campaign we mobilize all ARC volunteer network in 39 branches which every day they stand in main squares with donation box with moto "Donate for Ukrainian Red Cross in help of civilian population". Meanwhile, through our social media channels we encourage people and open the possibility  for them to donate online. 
Albanian Red Cross has participated in round table meeting organized by UNCR in Albania where participated representative of governmental institutions (Ministry of Interior) and other NGO-s.  The representatives of government declare that Ukrainian people that enter Albanian borders will be granted with status of temporary protection for 1 year. With request of UNCR and Ministry of interior its asked by all actors participating were asked to carry out the mapping capacities in response of possible refugee influx into Albania. 
 According to  Albanian Minister of Interior and Ukrainian Ambassador in Tirana until March 20, there are 351 Ukrainian persons with status of temporary protection. This people came an not organized way, privately and accommodated to their previous network as vacations relatives or connections. Structures of Ministry of Interior and Ukraine Embassy in Tirana has required to be registered.
field_reports.summary: Albania -  Ukraine Refugees

contacts.name: Pepe Sanchez / Iñigo Vila

field_reports.description: In almost a month of war in Ukraine, more than 26,000 people fleeing Ukraine have entered French territory and "10,500 Ukrainian nationals have been issued with a temporary residence permit" in France, "in application [of the] temporary protection status" proposed by the European Union, announced Jean Castex on Tuesday 22 March. The Prime Minister, who chaired a crisis unit for the reception of Ukrainian refugees at the Interior Ministry, said that 40% of these temporary residence permits had been issued "in the Ile-de-France region or in the Alpes-Maritimes".
field_reports.summary: France - Population Movement Ukraine
Ukrainian population movement

field_reports.description:
On the morning of February 24, it was announced that Russia had launched a military operation against Ukraine. According to the United Nations, as of March 18, 816 civilians lost their lives and 1.333 civilians were injured. People's access to basic services such as water, food and health is restricted in areas of active conflict, where civil infrastructure is damaged. According to the Ukrainian Government, the civilian casualties are much higher than reported.

Due to the conflicts in Ukraine, more than 6.500.000 people have been internally displaced in the last 26 days, but it is feared that this number will increase to 10 million. In addition, neighboring countries such as Poland, Romania, Hungary, Slovakia and Moldova opened their doors to Ukrainian asylum seekers, and as of March 18, at least 3.500.000 people fled the conflicts in the country and sought refuge in neighboring countries. The International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies (IFRC) issued a Preliminary Emergency Appeal of 100 Million Swiss Francs on February 28 to provide aid to 2 million people.
field_reports.summary: Turkish Red Crescent Ukraine Humanitarian Aid Operations Report

contacts.name: Irina Boicheva
contacts.title: Head of Strategic Partnership and International Relations

field_reports.description:
Ukraine is currently affected by a large-scale military conflict since 24.02.2022. Multiple military exercises in the region and along the eastern, northern, and southern borders of Ukraine predated the invasion of the country. Diplomatic push has failed to result in de-escalation.
As hostilities rage on, civilian casualties have risen to 2,032 as of 17 March – including 780 killed – according to the UN Office of the High Commissioner for Human Rights (OHCHR). These figures are likely much higher as reports are still being corroborated amid increasingly intense country-wide clashes.
The humanitarian situation in Mariupol is dire, with residents facing a critical and potentially fatal shortage of food, water, and medicines. Thousands of people reported to die inside the city.
Critical infrastructure is affected across the country, including bridges and railroads. Ministry of Health reported attacks on hospitals and clinics, shelling also targeted schools. Residential areas have been attacked by the multiple-launch rocket systems and other heavy weapons.
Nearly 4.9 million people have been forcibly displaced by the ongoing hostilities in Ukraine, including more than 3 million who have fled the country. Since 24 February, the UN Children’s Fund (UNICEF) says more than 1.5 million children have fled Ukraine – 75,000 on average per day.
field_reports.summary: Ukraine/ URCS response to the crisis
Ukraininan population movement

field_reports.description:
1) Since 25 February 2022, 17,882 people have officially declared their arrival from Ukraine to Lithuania. 7 705 of them are children. 483 are unaccompanied minors.
2) LRC volunteers and staff are operating in 5 Registration Centres nationwide: Alytus RC, Kaunas RC, Klaipėdos RC, Šiauliai RC, Vilnius RC.
3) Due to rapidly increasing number of arrivals, LRC is under process of reviewing its Operational Strategy and allocations of resources.
field_reports.summary: Lithuanian Red Cross humanitarian assistance to Ukraine

contacts.name: Pepe Sanchez / Iñigo Vila
contacts.title: Director Social Inclusion / Director Disaster Management

field_reports.description:
Influx of people is increasing, particularly since 11/04. Until then there had been isolated arrivals of people by their onw means and in most cases with relatives within the Ukrainian community in Spain. Since 11/04 arrivals are significantly increasing by trains thanks to the coordinated operation between SNCF and RENFE (French and Spanish railway main companies) that is providing free ticktes and coordinated transfers to several cities in Spain. Another mean is spontaneous transport facilitated by various citizenship initiatives.  It is expected that arrivals will increase exponentially in the coming days. 
Governement has articulated a super fast track procedure to grant temporary protection and the services related - residence and work pemit, access to public health and education system, etc.
field_reports.summary: Spain Population Movement Ukaine 16.03.2022
Ukrainian population movement

field_reports.description: Up to now, 140,800 people from Ukraine have registered with Austrian Authorities. Latest figures indicate that on average, aournd 10,000 people from Ukraine enter Austria on a daily basis by train or car, 80% of which are passing through to neighbouring countries. This figure has remained fairly constant over the past week. Based on official surveys and records, around 28,000 of those who have entered the country up to now are currently seeking permanent or semi-permanent residence.
field_reports.summary: Austrian Red Cross humanitarian assistance, Ukraine Crisis 15.03.2022

field_reports.description:
Between March 5rd and 8th 2022 the RoRC has supported the Ukrainian nationals currently within Romania with a total of 12.786 food items, 4449 hygiene kits, 1412 blankets and bedding items, 1205 baby products, 829 liters of water and 2000 first aid kits.
Between the 4th and 8th of March 2022, 6 of the RoRc branches have sent humanitarian transports into Ukraine, totaling 31168 food items, 8485 hygiene kits, 3143 blankets, 727 baby products, 4216 bottles of water and 3000 medical items.
On March 11 2022, a convoy of 8 trucks crossed the Siret border station, with destination Cernauti. 1 container was from the Chinese Red Cross, composed of blankets, non-perishable items, flashlights, clothing. The remaining 7 trucks were carrying 130 tons of non-perishable items, hygiene products, medical items and devices, medicine, baby products and bedding items. 
On March 14 2022, 2 shipping pallets of blankets and food items were distributed at the Siret border, and 11 boxes of pills and medical items were distributed to the Siret refugee center. Also on March 14, 1000 blankets and 1.5 tons of food aid were delivered to the Cernauti branch of the Ukrainian RC by the Suceava branch.
field_reports.summary: Romanian Red Cross humanitarian assistance to Ukraine

field_reports.description: LRC HQ has increased its procurement activities: LRC is purchasing more hygiene items as the number of arrivals from Ukraine are suspected to reach more than 20 000 by the end of next week.
field_reports.summary: Lithuanian Red Cross humanitarian assistance to Ukraine

contacts.title: Head of Country Delegation in Ukraine

field_reports.description:
Ukraine is currently affected by a large-scale military conflict since 24.02.2022. Multiple military exercises in the region and along the eastern, northern, and southern borders of Ukraine predated the invasion of the country. Diplomatic push has failed to result in de-escalation.
As the situation enters its second week, the human cost of the conflict continues to mount. Between 4 a.m. on 24 February and midnight on 10 March, the Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights (OHCHR) reports at least 1,507 civilian casualties, including 549 civilian deaths and 957 injuries. The number of civilians killed since 24 February already surpasses the 353 conflict-related civilian deaths recorded by OHCHR during six years of conflict in eastern Ukraine combined.
Military casualties are unknown now but can be estimated at around several thousand.
Critical infrastructure is affected across the country, including bridges, railroads. Ministry of Health reported attacks on hospitals and clinics, shelling also targeted schools. Residential areas have been attacked by the multiple-launch rocket systems.
At least 2,6 million people have already crossed into neighboring countries, according to the UNHCR on March 11.
field_reports.summary: Response to the conflict in Ukraine

field_reports.description:
Up to now, 89,600 people (from 76,500 as of 09.03. significant increase) from Ukraine have registered with Austrian Authorities. Daily arrivals are currently estimated at over 10,000 people, the Austrian Rail Service alone has reported 4,900 people (08.03). Around 86% state that they want to move on to other neighbouring countries.

Official accommodation capacities have been ramped up to 23.000 beds, not including Red Cross capacities (figures still pouring in from branches) or accommodation offered by private initiatives. Support services from the AutRC are - except for individual branch activities such as first aid or food-package provision for arrivals - linked to official services provided by the Austrian Governmnet. Arrivals need to contact a central 'Welcome Service' that redirects people to the respective institutions (incl. Red Cross) that provide shelter and primary care.
field_reports.summary: Austrian Red Cross humanitarian assistance, Ukraine Crisis Update 10.03.2022
Ukrainian population movement

field_reports.description:
After the escalation of the conflict in Ukraine, the first refuges started to come to Montenegro. According to the latest data from the Ministry of Interior, some 7.000 people from Ukraine entered Montenegro so far. However, as certain number of Ukrainian citizens have propriety in Montenegro, their accommodation is not yet facilitated by the state. Still, smaller number of them is asking for the Red Cross assistance. 
In addition to the provision of different type of assistance to the refugees in Montenegro, the Red Cross of Montenegro launched a national fundraising appeal, both via the bank account and SMS codes at three mobile operators in the country.
field_reports.summary: Refugees from Ukraine - Montenegro

field_reports.description:
1) Out of 4 611 people from Ukraine 40-45 % are children. Approximately 100 of them are unaccompanied minors.
2) Number of people from Ukraine that LRC provides assistance to on daily basis has increased 2.5 times, compared to last week (28th Feb 2022 - 6th March 2022). The average number of people approaching LRC branches was 253 and has increased to 702 people per day  .
3) LRC volunteers and staff are actively assisting Migration Department staff in registering newly arrived people at Vilnius and Alytus RCs.
4) LRC volunteers and staff are actively assisting other organisations in searching for permanent accommodation to people who arrive to Lithuania from Ukraine.
field_reports.summary: Lithuanian Red Cross humanitarian assistance to Ukraine

countries.society_name: The Red Cross Society of Bosnia and Herzegovina
countries.name: Bosnia and Herzegovina

field_reports.description:
After the conflict in Ukraine intensified during the last days of February, increasing numbers of refugees are leaving the county, escaping violence, arriving to other European countries. Even though most of the refugees are located in neighboring countries, some of them started arriving to Bosnia and Herzegovina. Specifically, during March 4 and 5 a total of 68 refugees arrived in Medjugorje region in Bosnia and Herzegovina, most of them to Citluk municipality. On March 6 another 42 people arrived. 2 of the refugees that arrived are men, 42 of the refugees are women, while the other 66 are children according to Red Cross data. There are also 5 unaccompanied minors aged 5-16 years. Currently there are 131 refugees. They arrived to Citluk since they have visited the location before as part of the religious pilgrimage. In the period after the initial influx, smaller numbers of people kept arriving. On March 16, a group of 20 people arrived to the municipality of Olovo. On March 18, another 50 people arrived to Citluk. In the meantime, smaller groups the size of one family have arrived in several towns in the country. 
Currently people are accommodated in private houses and apartments. This accommodation is temporary and there are no established accommodation sites in the country for now. Also, the accommodation units are far apart from each other, complicating the efforts for coordinated response. There are plans by authoroties about the objects and infrastructure which could be used for accommodation and those plans were shared with the RCSBH. Red Cross initiated activation of those plans, but also asked that the authoroties increase their capacities for accommodation and to activate objects that are more friendly for families. Federation of BiH government offered accommodation for 40 people in Hotel Walter in Sarajevo. Most of the people that are arriving don't expect to stay long in the country, hopping to get back to Ukraine when possible. There are information that more groups are on the way and could arrive to the same place in the following days.
field_reports.summary: Bosnia and Herzegovina - Refugees from Ukraine - 2022

field_reports.description:
On February 23rd, The National Security and Defence Council has decided to impose a state of emergency throughout Ukraine. States of emergency has been raised also in Lithuania and Moldova In the early morning hours of today, Russia's ground forces have crossed into Ukraine from North, East and South, including from Belorussian territory.  Explosions rang out before dawn Thursday, Feb 24th, in Ukraine's capital Kyiv and several cities near the contact-line and along the country's coast. Central European countries started preparations to receive potentially hundreds of thousands of people fleeing Ukraine. Departures of people leaving large cities have started mainly to the West of Ukraine, queues at supermarkets, gas stations, and banks are reported. Media reports mentioned the closing shipping in the Azov Sea between Ukraine and Russia.  Civilian airspace in Ukraine has been closed.
Until March 2nd, 2022, over 150.000 refugees are estimated to have crossed into Romania through all border stations.
field_reports.summary: Romanian Red Cross humanitarian assistance to Ukraine

field_reports.description:
1) Out of 1 600 people who arrived to Lithuania from Ukraine 700 are children.
2) LRC is actively promoting RFL activities to people registering at Alytus RC if, in worst case scenario, they lose connection with their relatives in Ukraine.
field_reports.summary: Lithuanian Red Cross humanitarian assistance to Ukraine

field_reports.description:
The Egyptian National Committee for Crisis Management and Disaster Risk Reduction (NCCMDRR) where ERC is part of it. they had agreed to position the ERC to have a role in facilitating the movement and data collection and providing support and accompanying the Egyptian Returnees from  Ukraine at the borders of the neighboring Ukrainian countries.

1st of March 2022, the Egyptian RC team composed of 2 staff had arrived with the Egyptian Ambassador of Romania and with a medical team to evacuate 175 Egyptian people form Romani - Bucharest airport. the ERC team provided medical and psychological support to them.

one day later, ERC had contacted the 175 people through the help line providing PFA over phone and international calls and rapid mental health assessment for the cases. 11 cases had been identified for following up with psychologist as they are affected by the traumatic event.

ERC is continue its support to them and for the upcoming returnees to provide Family tracing and mental health and psychosocial support and if needed rehabilitation services.

the Egyptian authority is requested support from ERC to coordinate with the RCRC NS in Ukraine and the neighboring NS to allow the ERC team to be deployed at the borders to facilitate the paper work and the all related support for the Egyptian returnees and to support the Egyptian Embassy at the countries in the evacuation process.
field_reports.summary: Egyptian Returnees from Ukraine

field_reports.description:
in Egypt, there are 17,000 Ukrainian people in Sharm Elsheikh and Hurghada. They are either tourists or workers. and based on the impact of the Ukraine crisis the 17,000 people are still in Egypt.

the Egyptian Public authority announced since the start the crisis to provide one week free accommodation at the hotels where they are hosted. and 14 days visa extension. and by Sunday 6 March 2022 a new updates from the Egyptian public authority will be announced.

ERC, as part of its response plan is going to:
- Enhance its preparedness capacities in the ERC branch in Hurghada and Sharm Elshikh.  
- all the warehouse to be in readiness statues.
- 100 specialized volunteers in MHPSS and Restoring Family links and relief are in stand by mood.
- ERC fleet to be well prepared and ready for operation.
- an Emergency plan of action is in place that include all sectors of response: livelihood, Health, WASH, Relief.
- contingency plan and coordination mechanism are in place.
field_reports.summary: Egypt: support to the Ukrainian people in Egypt
Hungary, population movement

field_reports.description:
1) Lithuanian Red Cross together with Vilnius City Municipality is working towards establishing two Registration Centres for people coming from Ukraine.
2) 36 trucks and 8 buses of donations left Lithuania on 1st March 2022. 1 of the trucks has already reached Ukraine.
3) 12 000 people in total have registered to become Red Cross volunteers. Lithuanian Red Cross is organising training sessions everyday in order to prepare new volunteers for action.
4) Lithuanian Red Cross is actively providing information related to migratory, accommodation, and humanitarian aid to people coming from Ukraine in multiple languages https://www.redcross.lt/paremkite/svarbi-informacija-ukrainieciams .
field_reports.summary: Lithuanian Red Cross humanitarian assistance to Ukraine
Lithuanian Red Cross humanitarian assistance to Ukraine
Lithuanian Red Cross humanitarian assistance to Ukraine

field_reports.description:
•	Ministry of Interior is coordinating the humanitarian aid operation. It is supported by the local governments at the voivodship level and number of NGOs, UN agencies and other stakeholders involved in humanitarian activities.
•	The border with Ukrain eis open for all refugees coming to Poland.
•	During the first 4 days of an armed conflict in Ukraine about 300 000 people crossed the border with Poland. Reception points are established. People receive more detailed information about stay in Poland, they are provided with temporary accommodation and receive a hot meals, drinks, basic medical assistance and a place to rest. From reception points, refugees are transported to places of temporary accommodation facilities, prepared in all voivodeships.
•	On Saturday 26th February morning, information points were also opened at railway stations in voivodship capitals. In Warsaw, such points are available at the following stations: East and West, as well as at Chopin Airport.
•	Central "large hub" for humanitarian aid will be launched near Lublin, which will be run by the Government Strategic Reserves Agency. From this hub all aid will be sent to Ukraine from international organizations and from many entities reporting that they want to help the invaded Ukraine and provide humanitarian aid.
field_reports.summary: Polish Red Cross humanitarian assistance to Ukraine

results.name: Ukraine and impacted countries crisis
results.summary:
On 24 February, a new phase in the armed conflict in Ukraine started with the intensification and spread of the hostilities that are now affecting most parts of the country and causing major concern for the protection of civilians and essential civilian infrastructure.

This rapid evolution of the situation on Ukraine’s borders and ongoing active military action inside Ukraine does not allow the humanitarian community to have much clarity on existing and immediate needs, particularly inside Ukraine. However, the needs are expected to be massive and to affect all regions of Ukraine, neighboring countries and beyond. 

Based on estimations provided by government authorities, international organizations and Red Cross National Societies, the total number of people now affected by the conflict is estimated to be up to 18 million. As of early May, there is an estimated 7.7 million displaced within Ukraine, with millions more living in active conflict zones who are facing a loss of electricity, difficulty accessing drinking water and severe shortages of medicines and available medical assistance. Over 5.6 million have fled the country since the beginning of the conflict - 1.3 million of which have reportedly returned to Ukraine. From available information, many returnees to Ukraine are not considered permanent, however, and that a significant portion of those returning are doing so in a pendular nature to check on family members or assess the safety or state of their homes.  

Poland has received the vast majority of those fleeing the conflict (over 3 million) followed by Romania and Hungary. The number of daily arrivals into neighboring countries continues to fluctuate, but has generally declined since the beginning of the crisis. In Poland, for example, daily arrivals remain close to 20,000 as of early May compared to an average of 100,000 daily arrivals in early March. In total, Ukrainians submitted over 21,000 applications for asylum in EU+ countries between February 21 and April 24. However, asylum applications quickly declined from early March, as the Temporary Protection Directive was activated on March 4, and was implemented by national authorities with the assistance of the EUAA.  According to provisional estimates, about 2.3 million persons fleeing Ukraine have been registered for temporary protection as of April 24 – less than half of those who have fled. The movement of people in need remains immensely complex and difficult to predict, but the situation is being monitored daily to anticipate needs, movements and developments in the conflict. We know that assistance at border points remains a large need – both in terms of information for those fleeing, as well as ensuring protection of those most vulnerable. Shelter needs are dynamic: many have been taken in by host families or relatives/friends in neighbouring countries, but for those in collective accommodation centres, needs for improved sanitation, personal care items and hygiene items remains a high priority. Finally, the need for financial assistance is ever-expanding, as people lose their primary sources of income, face unpredictable futures, and struggle to meet basic needs.

 

 

The current situation in Ukraine is governed by the four 1949 Geneva Conventions, its First Additional Protocol from 1977 and customary international humanitarian law. The International Red Cross Red Crescent Movement (the Movement) calls upon concerned authorities to support and facilitate the humanitarian response of Movement partners, including by ensuring that any restrictive measures contain effective protection of the humanitarian space, by managing any support to the parties responsibly as well as supporting the parties in fulfilling their responsibilities under International Humanitarian Law.

field_reports.description:
Chernivtsi region
June 20 at about 3 p.m. in Chernivtsi district due to bad weather (heavy rain) flooded by rain streams 80 houses in 8 settlements, 150 homesteads in 17 settlements, partially damaged local roads with a total length of about 30 km and pavement of 9 bridges in 29 settlements (passage) to settlements is provided). There are no casualties.
At 07.00 am. on June 21, the water level is gradually declining, basements in 29 residential buildings and 87 private plots in 15 settlements remain flooded, and the electricity supply to the village of Window.
On June 20, 35 people and 18 units SESU of equipment (including 7 motor pumps) were involved in the elimination of the consequences of the weather. In total, about 1,160 m3 of water was pumped out of 63 homesteads and 51 residential buildings. Work on pumping water continues.
The general coordination on overcoming the consequences of bad weather is carried out by Chernivtsi Regional State Administration.

Dnipropetrovsk region
At 07.00 am. on  June 21 in the city of Dnipro in the Amur-Lower Dnieper and Industrial districts due to difficult weather conditions (heavy rains continued during June 17-18) remain partially flooded 23 private houses and 102 homesteads since June 2, a total of 109 private houses and 200 households).
During the day on June 20, SESU units pumped out 56 thousand 288 m3 of water (since the beginning of works - 605218 m3 of water). Water pumping works are underway, 21 people and 21 units have been involved from the SESU equipment (including 14 motor pumps).
field_reports.summary: Ukraine Dnipropetrovsk Oblast, Chernivtsi Oblast Flood, 06/2021

results.name: Ukraine Dnipropetrovsk Oblast, Chernivtsi Oblast Fllods, 06/2021

field_reports.description:
Reportedly, the fires have affected at least 13,000 hectares of land and at least 32 settlements. Some 250 houses in GCA of Luhanska oblast have been damaged or destroyed so far. At least nine people have been killed, and 17 have been injured. In addition, at least 150 people have been reportedly evacuated. The EECP ‘Stanytsia Luhanska’ was closed  due to the fire that reached one of the roads leading to the crossing point. The fire has reportedly spread further and reached administrative modules (containers) at the EECP. At this time, almost half of the administrative premises are affected by the wildfire. In the meantime, hardware, communications, and medical equipment are being evacuated from the EECP’s territory. All civilians who were waiting to cross the ‘contact line’ through the EECP were evacuated. The evacuation activities will be continue if civilians will arrive to the border line.
The firefighting activities continue, and the situation remains precarious due to strong winds (20-30 m/sec) that often change their direction. Since the surrounding territory is contaminated with mines/UXOs, reportedly, there were some detonations caused by the fire. The firefighters have also managed to contain the fire’s spread to the Sievierodonetsk Azot Association – one of the largest chemical enterprises in Ukraine – preventing a potential environmental hazard
field_reports.summary: Ukraine, Eastern part, Luhansk region, Wildfire, 2020/10/01

results.name: Ukraine, Eastern part, Luhansk region, Wildfire, 2020/10/01
